title: 6042 Cheshirecat
text:
6042 Cheshirecat ( "or" ), provisional designation , is an eccentric, rare-type <a href="asteroid">asteroid</a> and large <a href="Mars-crosser">Mars-crosser</a> from the outer regions of the <a href="asteroid%20belt">asteroid belt</a>, approximately 14 kilometers in diameter. It was discovered by Japanese astronomers <a href="Akira%20Natori">Akira Natori</a> and <a href="Takeshi%20Urata">Takeshi Urata</a> at the <a href="JCPM%20Yakiimo%20Station">JCPM Yakiimo Station</a> on 23 November 1990. It was named for the <a href="Cheshire%20Cat">Cheshire Cat</a> from the novel "<a href="Alice%27s%20Adventures%20in%20Wonderland">Alice's Adventures in Wonderland</a>".
Classification and orbit.
"Cheshirecat" is a <a href="Mars-crossing%20asteroid">Mars-crossing asteroid</a>, as it crosses the orbit of <a href="Mars">Mars</a> at 1.666 <a href="Astronomical%20unit">AU</a>. It orbits the Sun at a distance of 1.65–4.43 <a href="Astronomical%20unit">AU</a> once every 5 years and 4 months (1,936 days). Its orbit has an <a href="orbital%20eccentricity">eccentricity</a> of 0.46 and an <a href="orbital%20inclination">inclination</a> of 16<a href="Degree%20%28angle%29">°</a> with respect to the <a href="ecliptic">ecliptic</a>.
The body's <a href="observation%20arc">observation arc</a> begins 11 years prior to its official discovery observation, with a <a href="precovery">precovery</a> taken at the <a href="Siding%20Spring%20Observatory">Siding Spring Observatory</a> in August 1979.
Physical characteristics.
According to photometry from the <a href="Sloan%20Digital%20Sky%20Survey">Sloan Digital Sky Survey</a>, "Cheshirecat" is a rare <a href="K-type%20asteroid">K-type asteroid</a>. The asteroid has also been characterized as a XL-type – which transitions from the <a href="X-type%20asteroid">X-type</a> to the <a href="L-type%20asteroid">L-type asteroid</a> – by <a href="Pan-STARRS">Pan-STARRS</a> photometric survey.
Lightcurves.
In December 2006, a rotational <a href="lightcurve">lightcurve</a> of "Cheshirecat" was obtained from photometric observations by American astronomer <a href="Robert%20D.%20Stephens">Robert Stephens</a>. Lightcurve analysis gave a <a href="rotation%20period">rotation period</a> of 10.050 hours with a brightness variation of 0.40 <a href="Magnitude%20%28astronomy%29">magnitude</a> (). In September 2011, another lightcurve, obtained at the Oakley Southern Sky Observatory (), Australia, gave a concurring period of 10.050 hours and an amplitude of 0.20 ()
Diameter and albedo.
According to the survey carried out by the Japanese <a href="Akari%20%28satellite%29">Akari satellite</a>, "Cheshirecat" measures 14.12 kilometers in diameter and its surface has an <a href="astronomical%20albedo">albedo</a> of 0.109. The "Collaborative Asteroid Lightcurve Link" assumes a standard albedo for <a href="C-type%20asteroid">carbonaceous asteroids</a> of 0.057 and calculates a diameter of 14.64 kilometers based on an <a href="absolute%20magnitude">absolute magnitude</a> of 12.9.
Naming.
This <a href="minor%20planet">minor planet</a> was named for the <a href="Cheshire%20Cat">Cheshire Cat</a>, a cat appearing in <a href="Lewis%20Carroll">Lewis Carroll</a>'s famous fairy tale "<a href="Alice%20in%20Wonderland">Alice in Wonderland</a>". The cat is known for its distinctive mischievous grins and eyes that linger after it has already faded away. The asteroid's name and citation was proposed by co-discoverer <a href="Takeshi%20Urata">Takeshi Urata</a>. The approved naming citation was published by the <a href="Minor%20Planet%20Center">Minor Planet Center</a> on 2 February 1999 ().
